record.title: Classical macroeconomic model for the United States, a / Thomas J. Sargent.
record.creator: Sargent, Thomas J.
record.contributor: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Research Dept.
record.subject: Rational expectations (Economic theory)--United States.
Unemployment--United States--Statistical methods.
Macroeconomics--Econometric models.
E24 - Macroeconomics : Consumption, saving, production, employment, and investment - Employment ; Unemployment ; Wages ; Intergenerational income distribution ; Aggregate human capital
E17 - General aggregative models - Forecasting and simulation
record.description: Natural unemployment rate ; Montarist model ; Postwar United States ; post-1945 ; Rational expectations theory
record.abstract: A statistical definition of the natural unemployment rate hypothesis is advanced and tested. A particular illustrative structural macroeconomic model satisfying the definition is set forth and estimated. The model has "classical" policy implications, implying a number of neutrality propositions asserting the invariance of the conditional means of real variables with respect to the feedback rule for the money supply. The aim is to test how emphatically the data reject a model incorporating rather severe "classical" hypotheses.
record.isPartOf: Working paper (Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Research Dept.)
record.publisher: Minneapolis : Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis

record.title: Interest on reserves / Thomas Sargent, Neil Wallace.
record.creator: Sargent, Thomas J.
Wallace, Neil.
record.contributor: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Research Dept.
record.subject: Equilibrium (Economics)
Interest rates.
Bank reserves--Mathematical models.
E43 - Money and interest rates - Determination of interest rates ; Term structure of interest rates
D58 - General equilibrium and disequilibrium - Computable and other applied general equilibrium models
record.description: Reserves ; Interest rates ; General equilibrium models
record.abstract: In a general equilibrium setting, we study versions of the proposal to pay interest on reserves at the market rate. We argue that the proposal makes the demand for total reserves indeterminate whether interest is paid on total reserves or on required reserves only. One consequence is that tax financing of the proposal gives rise to a continuum of equilibria, equilibria which differ in real returns and consumption allocations. Another consequence is that an attempt to finance the proposal through earnings on the central bank’s portfolio either gives rise to an equilibrium with a zero nominal interest rate or fails to give rise to an equilibrium.
record.isPartOf: Working paper (Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Research Dept.)
record.publisher: Minneapolis : Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis

record.title: Forecasting and conditional projection using realistic prior distributions / Thomas Doan, Robert Litterman, Christopher Sims.
record.creator: Doan, Thomas.
Litterman, Robert B.
Sims, Christopher A.
record.contributor: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Research Dept.
record.subject: Economic forecasting--Statistics.
Economic forecasting--Mathematical models.
E27 - Macroeconomics : Consumption, saving, production, employment, and investment - Forecasting and simulation
C11 - Econometric and statistical methods : General - Bayesian analysis
record.description: Forecasting ; Bayesian methods ; Macroeconomics
record.abstract: This paper develops a forecasting procedure based on a Bayesian method for estimating vector autoregressions. The procedure is applied to ten macroeconomic variables and is shown to improve out-of-sample forecasts relative to univariate equations. Although cross-variables responses are damped by the prior, considerable interaction among the variables is shown to be captured by the estimates. We provide unconditional forecasts as of 1982:12 and 1963:3* We also describe how a model such as this can be used to make conditional projections and to analyse policy alternatives. As an example, we analyze a Congressional Budget Office forecast made in 1982:12. While no automatic causal interpretations arise from models like ours, they provide a detailed characterization of the dynamic statistical interdependence of a set of economic variables, which may help in evaluating causal hypotheses, without containing any such hypotheses themselves.
record.isPartOf: Working paper (Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Research Dept.)
record.publisher: Working paper (Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Research Dept.)

record.title: Wage and price dynamics in U. S. manufacturing / John Geweke.
record.creator: Geweke, John.
record.contributor: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Research Department.
record.subject: Wages--Manufacturing industries.
Manufacturing industries--Economic aspects--United States--Econometric methods
E32 - Prices, business fluctuations, and cycles - Business fluctuations ; Cycles
L60 - Industry Studies: Manufacturing: General
E31 - Price Level; Inflation; Deflation
record.description: Wages ; Prices ; Manufacturing ; Wholesale ; Labor
record.abstract: A simple stochastic model of the firm is constructed in which a dynamic monopolist who maximizes a discounted profits stream subject to labor adjustment costs and given factor prices sets output price as a distributed lag of past wages and input prices. If the observed relation of wages and prices in manufacturing arises solely from this behavior then wages and input prices are exogenous with respect to output prices. In tests using quarterly and monthly series for the straight time wage, an index of raw materials prices and the wholesale price index for manufacturing and its durable and nondurable subsectors this hypothesis cannot be refuted for the period 1955:1 to 1971:11. During the period 1926:1 to 1940:11, however, symmetrically opposite behavior is observed manufacturing wholesale prices are exogenous with respect to the wage rate, a relation which can arise if dynamically monopsonistic firms compete in product markets. Neither structural relation has withstood direct wage and price controls.
record.relation: New methods in business cycle research
record.publisher: Minneapolis : Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis

record.title: Classical macroeconometric model for the United States, a / Thomas J. Sargent.
record.creator: Sargent, Thomas J.
record.contributor: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Research Department.
record.subject: Labor economics.
Unemployment--Econometric models.
Macroeconomics.
E17 - General Aggregative Models: Forecasting and Simulation
C53 - Forecasting and Other Model Applications
J01 - Labor Economics: General
record.abstract: A statistical definition of the natural unemployment rate hypothesis is advanced and tested. A particular illustrative structural macroeconomic model satisfying the definition is set forth and estimated. The model has "classical" policy implications, implying a number of neutrality propositions asserting the invariance of the conditional means of real variables with respect to the feedback rule for the money supply. The aim is to test how emphatically the data reject a model incorporating rather severe "classical" hypotheses.
record.unmapped: Published version appears in the Journal of Political Economy, April 1976.

record.title: Estimation of dynamic labor demand schedules under rational expectations / Thomas J. Sargent.
record.creator: Sargent, Thomas J.
record.contributor: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Research Department.
record.subject: Monetary policy--Mathematical models.
record.abstract: A dynamic linear demand schedule for labor is estimated and tested. The hypothesis of rational expectations and assumptions about the orders of the Markov processes governing technology impose over-identifying restrictions on a vector autoregression for straight-time employment, overtime employment, and the real wage. The model is estimated by the full information maximum likelihood method. The model is used as a vehicle for re-examining some of the paradoxical cyclical behavior of real wages described in the famous Dunlop-Tarshis-Keynes exchange.
record.isPartOf: Staff report (Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Research Dept.)
record.publisher: Minneapolis : Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis.
